conclusion: Identify the two straight segments that actually carry current: segment ac of length L is vertical; segment cd of length 2L is horizontal.
The magnetic field B is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
Each straight segment experiences a magnetic (Ampère) force of magnitude F = I L B sin θ, where θ is the angle between the segment and B.
Because B is perpendicular to the plane, θ = 90° for every straight segment, hence sin θ = 1.
Each segment therefore feels a force whose magnitude equals the product I L B times its own length.
Vertical segment ac: F₁ = I B L.
Horizontal segment cd: F₂ = I B (2 L) = 2 I B L.
These forces act on directions that are perpendicular to the respective wire segments and lie in the plane.
Segment ac (current upward) → force points toward the right (use right-hand rule).
Segment cd (current to the right) → force points downward.
The two force vectors are mutually perpendicular.
Magnitude of the resultant force on the bent wire is the vector sum of the perpendicular components: F = √( F₁² + F₂² ) = √[ (I B L)² + (2 I B L)² ].
Calculate the magnitude of the resultant force: F = I B L √(1 + 4) = I B L √5.
The magnitude of the net Ampère force acting on the bent current-carrying wire is F = √5 I B L.
